review: Read this on the plane on my way home from a vacation in St. Lucia as I was trying to understand how it is possible that 737,000 people a year visit tRead this on the plane on my way home from a vacation in St. Lucia as I was trying to understand how it is possible that 737,000 people a year visit the island, but its major cities — Castries and in particular, Soufrière, show few signs of affluence. Soufrière was in terrible shape when we visited (March, 2024). It looked deserted and broken, cracked windows and front doors boarded up instead of replaced. Where were the people? Where was the commerce? The book, which does in fact, read like a well-paced novel, as others have noted, provided history and context. I liked that it was written from a distinct POV — this is not a cautious and objective recitation of the facts — it’s a passionate, insider account of the troubles that generations of St. Lucians have endured and continue to endure. I thought the author’s descriptions of the intensely physical labours performed by inhabitants over the centuries — from slavery to slinging coal and farming bananas — contained a level of detail one rarely encounters in history books and which may not have been recorded in any meaningful way at all, if not for this book. Reynolds has lived the history of which he speaks, and it makes for a riveting read. He did mention that the types of tourism that is popular in St. Lucia — cruise ships and all-inclusive resorts — do not result in trickle down prosperity. I would have liked to have heard his thoughts on that subject. To be fair, tourism was not the topic of his book, which was published in 2018. I finished the book feeling like I’d had a fascinating encounter with a thoughtful, highly educated and erudite resident of the island. I would recommend this book to anyone with an interest in Caribbean history or who is seeking to better understand events taking place in the Caribbean today. Haiti may be the first island nation to descend into lawlessness, but as this book makes clear, you can only keep people poor and oppressed for a finite amount of generations, even though those generations may be legion.The murder rate in St. Lucia is climbing — 39 homicides per 100,000 people a year in 2021, compared to about 2 in Canada and about 6 in the U.S. There were 75 homicides in St. Lucia in 2023.While tourists are not the target, it is hard not to see it as evidence that a new, dark chapter in the history of the island is about to be written....more

The subject matter appealed to me — American wives, as did the place — Vietnam, and the time period — the 1960s. But not enough happened. Or maybe not in the right order. I feel the book may better have held my interest if it had started with the main characters being stuck in a jeep in the pouring rain, night falling as fear of a Viet Cong attack grows, and then back-tracked to how they got there. Or maybe not, because the bottom line is, not enough happened to sustain my interest over 324 pages. Example: The narrator attaches so much importance to the “you” she’s addressing that you imagine she adopted her or that they became lovers or…something. But no. Nothing really happens. They move away. The last part of the book, supposedly written by a different person of a different generation has a voice almost identical to the first narrator. McDermott is making a point with this book, I suppose. A point about our instinct to help and how it can backfire, get warped, miss the point, make things worse, and how great good can come from great evil — the dodgy surgeon who goes on to pioneer life-saving heart surgery. Morality isn’t black-and-white — even people doing good can wreak harm. And sometimes the most important things that happen in our lives aren’t big events, but relatively small ones, that loom larger as they ripple across time, across generations. review: **spoiler alert** Child celebrities make me uncomfortable. So do child prodigies and athletes. Generally speaking, they’re giving up their one, brief **spoiler alert** Child celebrities make me uncomfortable. So do child prodigies and athletes. Generally speaking, they’re giving up their one, brief childhood to chase a dream that may or may not pan out, and if it does pan out and bring fame, we’ll, that’s not a great outcome either. It doesn’t seem worth it and shouldn’t be encouraged. I mean, maybe if it’s something they are themselves obsessed with and want — maybe — it’s okay? Maybe. Too often it seems to be something their parents want for them. That was Jennette McCurdy’s experience. At the age of six, her mother Debra began pushing her only daughter into acting, eventually making a star out of her — McCurdy landed the lead role in iCarly on Nickelodeon. Debra also introduced her daughter to extreme dieting in order to delay puberty, which triggered anorexia and then bulimia. Debra was a hoarder whose children slept on Costco mats on the living room floor, hemmed in by garbage. Three of them were the product of an affair with another man, while Debra was married to Mark, the man Jennette thought was her father — a passive retail worker whom Debra controlled with her explosive rage. It took McCurdy years to disentangle her life from her overbearing mother, and it sadly seems unlikely that she will ever be fully and truly healed — the abuse she suffered infused every nook and cranny of her life. And in L.A., stars seem hounded at every turn by predators, from overzealous fans to opportunistic real estate agents, contractors, even decorators, and leering and emotionally abusive directors. Even her attempts at recovery are fraught. Her first “therapist” quickly crosses all boundaries, persuading Jennette to take her to an awards show, for “therapeutic” reasons. The therapist ends up spending more time canoodling with stars than she does helping her client. The last chapters of the book are wrenching. McCurdy sits by her mother’s headstone, inscribed with superlatives, and is swamped by anger over who her mother really was and what she did to the people closest to her, the closest being her. McCurdy’s assessment of her mother in these pages is scathing.I actually read this book by accident. It was recommended to me, I thought, by a well-read family member. Turns out I completely messed up the title and read the wrong book entirely.I don’t regret it. Like all people who grew up with a monster in the house — someone whose moods must constantly be read accurately in order to keep all hell from breaking loose — McCurdy is an expert in reading people. Her assessments seem accurate, and even in the case of her mother, she demonstrates an underlying reflexive kindness, understanding and humanity that to me signal deep intelligence. His happiness depends on his mom’s choice in men, which is bizarrely terrible. Together Tobias and his mother flee a string of abusive husbands and boyfriends, taking refuge in Utah, Seattle and finally a small town in Washington, where Wolff is forced to live with a step-father who loathes him. The boy takes up with a variety of dodgy friends, and engages in random pranks, any one of which could have killed him, and yet somehow survives, mostly unscathed, to mess up a new day. He steals. He lies and cheats his way into a prep school, winning the support of a school official who invests in him, but he messes that up too and gets kicked out.The story ends before we learn how the boy finally rights himself, becoming an award-winning writer and professor. This book is almost perfectly written, but there’s a curious detachment about it — a lack of emotion. It also seems truthful, at times unsparing. The blurb on the back of the 30th anniversary edition of the book, published in 2019, says: Thirty years ago Tobias Wolff wrote a memoir that changed the form. This novel has been described as the Great Gay Novel, but I doubt it is that. I feel like that book remains to be written, and probably by a gay man. I feel like this is a novel about sexual abuse — all sexual abuse is heinous, but there are layers and degrees to everything, even in hell, and here Yanagihara writes about the kind of sexual abuse practised by the utterly depraved; by monsters disguised as average men. It’s not giving anything away to say this; it becomes clear early on that the main character, Jude, has suffered grievously; sustaining perhaps irreparable damage. (It is the ´perhaps’ that keeps us going in part — can he or can he not be saved?)This novel is also about friendship; the kind of friendships and lifelong collaborations found mostly in books and movies — deep friendships that endure more than 30 years — when in real life real friendships wax and wane and founder more often than not, accidents and frequent victims of geography. (In fact I found this to be the least credible part of the book.) It’s also, interestingly, about the uniquely American ways in which it is possible to become successful, success unique perhaps, the author hints, to New York City, the spoils of which include multiple residences, global travel and booking historic monuments in Spain for three private hours as a birthday present.But it is when Yanagihara deals with horror of sexual abuse — predators bring their own sheets to motel appointments; victims never feel clean again; the scars are something no amount of love and success can erase — it is here that the novel rings truest and is at its most searing. One gets the impression that the author has either done tremendous research; has perhaps (and I hope not) been through it herself or knows someone who has. If none of these things are true, Yanagihara is an empath and her imagination, genius.Almost every sentence in this book is perfect. I often find books to be too long; even 300-page books. I think, generally speaking, that we tend to think of people in different times as lacking the full range of emotions we ourselves feel. We think they were grim, humourless and obedient. But people have been laughing and working and scheming and falling in love like maniacs since there were people, driving them to do all kinds of crazy random stuff, including undertaking a pilgrimage to Spain with an infant to find a lost love. Anyway, this book is an interesting romp through England (and parts of Europe) from 1123 to 1174, starting with the sinking of a ship carrying the heir to the British throne and ending with the murder of Thomas Beckett and King Henry’s atonement. Along the 973 pages, we learn what it was like to live as a peasant, an earl, a priest and a king, and what it was like to be a woman, utterly without power in the world. review: I began this book dubiously, with a big fat chip on my shoulder. I rolled my eyes and nearly returned it. A couple of things kept me going — George FlI began this book dubiously, with a big fat chip on my shoulder. I rolled my eyes and nearly returned it. A couple of things kept me going — George Floyd’s death at the hands of a Minnesota police officer and the resulting worldwide protests; the numerous videos surfacing that show police using excessive force against people of colour, and the fact that a colleague once described my reaction to something he said as an example of white fragility. Him saying that stopped me cold. I had never heard the expression before — it was newer then. I felt that it was incumbent upon me to learn more.Also, DiAngelo is no newbie. She has impressive academic credentials and works as an anti racist educator. She has been reading and thinking deeply about this issue for a long time and I respected that enough to persevere. She’s also not a terrible writer.She snagged me in the beginning by pointing out something I didn’t know. We commonly say that women got the vote in the US in 1920. But the truth is, white women got the vote in 1920. Black women got the vote in 1965. There is not one history, there are many, and one is Black and one is white. Her central thesis is this, that people in North America live in a society that is deeply separate and unequal by race, and white people are the beneficiaries of that separation and inequality. This insulates white people from racial stress — a burden Black people carry with them at all times — and white people feel entitled to and deserving of the advantage this gives them. Because whites rarely experience racial discomfort, we have no stamina when it comes to addressing issues of race, DiAngelo argues. We crumple easily, are defensive and lash out when we are accused of being racist, even when we’re being racist.The fact that there remains an absurd disparity in conditions between whites and Blacks is evidence that we live in a racist society, she argues. Whites still rule most institutions, including police, the legal system and business. It’s mostly Blacks and people of colour who populate prisons.She begins with how white came to be as a concept, first appearing in colonial law in the late 1600s, to protect and preserve white superiority and dominance and rationalize slavery, but moves quickly to the present day and remains there for most of the book. White people, she argues, need to understand that racism is not an event — it’s not just rednecks flying confederate flags — it’s an intricate system and white people need to understand how they support that system, even white people who don’t believe they are racist, perhaps because they have Black friends or marched for civil rights in the 1960s.She points to an advantage I didn’t know whites have but as soon as I read it I knew it was true — we enjoy psychological freedom from the tether of race. I could relate immediately, because I see daily how white men enjoy psychological freedom from having to think about things like personal safety from sexual assault or more mundane things, like how a household functions or how social relationships are maintained. Whites don’t carry the psychic weight of race, which frees them to be more productive, which leads them to be more successful. It allows us to perceive our experience as universal, when it is not. It allows us to see ourselves as individuals instead of as members of a particular race. It allows us to believe that we live in a meritocracy when we do not. Segregation deprives all of us, DiAngelo points out. How much richer would our lives be if we interacted in a meaningful way with Black people instead of offering little more than superficial acceptance? DiAngelo argues that we must pull this racist system up by its roots, and our role, as white people, is to do start doing the work — to deeply examine what we think and why we think it and to challenge racist beliefs and practices when we encounter them. The resources are out there, she says — there are so many books to read and courses to take. It’s time we started reading them and reflecting and making meaningful change. I would recommend this book to anyone. It’s not an easy read but it’s a necessary read....more

The characters are stock characters — the shiny socialite somewhat lacking in substance; the kind, average husband, startled and grateful to be married to her, incapable of deep passion; the feckless former lover, still enamoured decades later; the girl she kissed in college, now the contented mother of five sons. None of these characters are unique in the way that Ignatius J. Reilly is in A Confederacy of Dunces, or Owen Meany in A Prayer for Owen Meany. Nor did Woolf invent stream-of-consciousness writing — Proust did it earlier and more exquisitely and James Joyce is recognized as the English language master of the form. So what is it about this book that endures?Woolf wasn’t striving to create unique characters with Mrs. Dalloway, she was seeking to turn ordinary characters inside out, to expose their interior lives, including the parts they keep hidden from themselves, and to look at them through the eyes of other characters.It works best with Septimus, a WWI soldier who, like Woolf, suffers from a mental illness. (He has PTSD, she probably suffered from bi-polar disorder, which must have been terrible, with no pharmaceutical interventions available). When she describes how carefully he decides to look up, for example, unsure of whether what he will see is real or unreal — she may be drawing directly on experience, and that gives it power. review: Meh. I go through periods of disenchantment with fiction and books like this are the reason why. Pachinko is a New York Times best-seller; a national Meh. I go through periods of disenchantment with fiction and books like this are the reason why. Pachinko is a New York Times best-seller; a national book award finalist; declared one of 2017’s 10 best books by the NYT Book Review, and it really, truly, is nothing special. Characters are drawn and things happen to them, their children, grandchildren and great-grandchildren and on for nearly 500 long pages. Min Jin Lee has some insight — she’s an older writer with personal experience to draw on, but I can count the number of interesting insights on the fingers of one hand. The prose is serviceable at best. The characters include a prostitute with a heart of gold. People are born and marry, and then bam, they die, and the chapter ends and it’s many years later and you’re left feeling...nothing. Resentfully, at the halfway mark, when I realized it was definitely not going to get better, I soldiered stubbornly on. How can the NYT be wrong? How can so many book buyers be wrong? How does the whole system conspire to push something so mediocre to the top of the pile?I learned things I didn’t know — the relationship between Japan and Korea and the discrimination experienced by Koreans living in Japan were new and interesting to me. But the book was devoid, to me, of suspense. I kept turning the pages out of idle interest, not because I ever became invested in the characters.I read every word, including the interview with the author at the end, and oddly, I found that to be the most interesting part of the book. Maybe Lee should stick to non-fiction.In a world with so many amazing books to read, and recognizing that life is short, I wouldn’t recommend this book to anyone. Not that my opinion matters. title: A Mother's Reckoning: Living in the Aftermath of Tragedy
author: Klebold, Sue
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Holding her newborn baby in her arms, Sue Klebold experiences a deep feeling of foreboding: “It was as if a bird of prey had passed overhead, casting Holding her newborn baby in her arms, Sue Klebold experiences a deep feeling of foreboding: “It was as if a bird of prey had passed overhead, casting us into shadow. I was overcome by a strong premonition: This child would bring me a terrible sorrow.”And he did. Dylan Klebold joined his friend and classmate Eric Harris on a murderous assault at Columbine High School, in Littleton, Colorado, that was at the time described as the worst school shooting in history. Which it wasn’t. A school shooting in Montréal a decade earlier had claimed 14 women, plus the shooter. Twelve students and one teacher were killed at Columbine. Including Klebold and Harris, the total was also 15.This book is a long apology from Klebold to her son’s victims — the dead, the wounded and their families. She says she never saw it coming; did not know her son was so angry, depressed, homicidal. He went to his prom and had a great time. He was planning to attend college in Arizona in the fall. He bussed his own dishes after supper every night. Klebold goes into detail about Dylan’s upbringing, which was filled with Little League games and movie nights and attentive parenting coupled with loving discipline. She reports only one terrible fight between her and Dylan, in which she pins him up against the fridge, jabbing her finger at him and yelling. He calmly asks her to stop, because he says, he is getting angry and he doesn’t know if he’ll be able to control himself. She stops. They hug. Overall, she describes a home filled with love and warmth and affection. Despite that, there seemed to have also been a lot of conflict between her and her husband and their eldest son, Byron. My impression is that as parents the Klebolds may have perhaps been too involved in the lives of their sons; too restrictive; too instructional, perhaps even overbearing. But that’s the kind of thing that should inspire annoyance, not homicidal rage. One small contradiction stood out for me: Klebold said money was an issue in the home, and they worried about how they would pay for Dylan’s college education, but pages later, explains that she and her husband bought rental properties. I suppose there’s a way to explain that, but it did stick out.Klebold blames herself for not recognizing Dylan’s psychological decline and for not doing anything about it. A lifelong educator, she seems to have written the book to exculpate herself but also to warn other parents what to look for. She does discuss the bullying Dylan was subjected to at school and it sounds extreme. In one instance, he was circled by a group of kids who squirted ketchup on him. Another time kids at the school drove past him and threw trash out the window at him. Columbine High School in 1999 sounds like a horrible place to be, if you weren’t a jock or the prettiest girl in the school. I feel like the well-established culture of bullying at the school was probably a bigger factor than Sue and Tom Klebold’s parenting. Reading between the lines, it doesn’t seem to me that Dylan was headed towards a bright future, even if he hadn’t fallen in with Harris, who has been described as a psychopath. Dylan seemed instead to be headed towards deepening mental illness which, if it were something like depression maybe, maybe, would have cleared by itself had he been successful at college under sunny Arizona skies. That seems unlikely, given how tall and awkward and shy and unattractive he was. He was immature and painfully self-conscious. He didn’t seem equipped to handle the social demands of college life, but it’s possible, had he been lucky enough to fall in with a good group of friends, that things may have turned out okay for him.Harris was a psychopath, his journals filled with rage and dreams of violence. Dylan’s journals were rambling and confused and full of hearts — he needed someone to find him and see him and choose him to love.There are many lessons to be learned from everything that happened at Columbine. This book is an important part of that. It took me a long time to decide to read it, because I didn’t want to immerse myself in the subject matter. Reading it was difficult and it left me feeling bad, to be honest. But also more informed. Everyone who thinks of reading it has to decide if what they may learn is worth the difficult journey of reading this book. I feel like I barely broke even....more

It features a large cast of characters, who each have at least one nickname but not always enough personal information to create a lasting impression in the mind of the reader. Emily is repeatedly referred to as small and tiny -- from her feet to her face.Some of the detail is fantastic and reveals much, for example, the descriptions of the girls preparing for a party, but there is much detail that is tedious, including more than a paragraph about a lamp.The plot is a good one and so is the point-of-view, or points of view, as the story is told through the eyes of the different characters. It rings truest in the parts dealing with the Metis police officer, which is perhaps not surprising as the writer is herself Metis. There are some interesting plot twists.
